metadata.source: John Cleaver Self Discription (1956), Marston DISC Theory (1928)

D.name: Dominance
D.swedish_description: Lägger tonvikten på resultat, utmaning, noggrannhet

I.name: Influence
I.swedish_description: Lägger tonvikten på att påverka andra, öppenhet, relationer

S.name: Steadiness
S.swedish_description: Lägger tonvikten på samarbete, uppriktighet, pålitlighet

C.name: Conscientiousness
C.motto: Do it right or don't do it
C.swedish_description: Lägger tonvikten på kvalité, detaljer, kompetens

Developer.disc_combination: D high (only dimension above midline); I, S, C all low
Developer.description: Developers are self-reliant individuals who seek their own creative and individualistic solutions to problems. Strong-willed and free from constraining influences, they are most interested in opportunities for advancement and accomplishing self-set goals. A challenge to them is 'like meat to a lion.' They have high expectations of themselves and others and become critical when standards are not met. Their intense focus on results can make them seem impatient and uncaring.
weaknesses: Attempts to control people and situations
Forgets to include others in problem-solving
Developer.communication_style: Direct, blunt, bottom-line oriented. Prefers brief exchanges with minimal small talk. Dislikes repeating information or generalizations. Focuses narrowly on solutions, not problems. Values efficiency above all in communication.
Developer.work_environment: Needs variety of challenges and room for independence. Dislikes routine work. Prefers fast-paced, results-driven settings with opportunities for advancement and freedom to shape their own approach.
Developer.leadership_style: Commanding and decisive. Takes charge naturally, makes quick decisions, provides clarity during uncertainty. Excels in crisis situations where speed is essential. May bulldoze team input and move too quickly without bringing others along.
Developer.stress_behaviors: Becomes belligerent, impatient, harsh, and may monopolize conversations or railroad decisions
Developer.decision_making: Quick and decisive—acts immediately and adjusts later rather than analyzing extensively. Views time as a critical asset.
Developer.conflict_style: Head-on. Addresses issues quickly and decisively. Direct and assertive. May assert views so strongly others feel pressured into agreement. Competitive approach creates win/lose dynamics. Respects equally direct opponents.
Developer.team_value: Innovative problem solver—the buck stops with them

Results_Oriented.disc_combination: D high (primary); I moderate-high (secondary above midline); S and C low
Results_Oriented.description: Results-Oriented individuals seek to accomplish results above all else. They value independence and display a self-confidence that some perceive as arrogance. Competitive by nature, they gravitate toward difficult tasks and high positions. They exude a sense of self-importance and display visible self-satisfaction when completing responsibilities. The key distinction from the Developer is that the I secondary gives them more social awareness, though they primarily channel this social energy toward driving results rather than building relationships for their own sake.
core_strengths: Ability to influence through force of character
weaknesses: Makes judgments solely on results capability
Results_Oriented.communication_style: Direct and forceful. High confidence in self-expression. Values efficiency. More socially aware than the Developer due to I secondary but uses charm strategically for results. Critical and fault-finding when displeased.
Results_Oriented.work_environment: High positions with independence and control. Competitive environments with difficult, challenging tasks. Freedom from routine. Results-driven culture valuing measurable accomplishment and recognition.
Results_Oriented.leadership_style: Leads with determination and force of character. Sets high standards. Creates competitive dynamics. Most effective when channeling the I secondary—practicing patience, showing concern, and soliciting team input.
Results_Oriented.stress_behaviors: Becomes fault-finding, critical, oversteps boundaries. Competitive behaviors escalate
Results_Oriented.decision_making: Quick and decisive. Judges decisions by whether they produce results. Would benefit from slowing down to think through consequences.
Results_Oriented.conflict_style: Directly confrontational. Persistent even facing antagonism. Blunt and uncaring in disputes. Creates win/lose through competition. Critical and fault-finding when stressed.

Inspirational.disc_combination: D high (primary, slightly above I); I high (nearly equal to D, both above midline); S and C low
Inspirational.description: Inspirational individuals influence the thoughts and actions of others, directing behavior toward predetermined goals. The defining characteristic is that D and I are nearly equal—the I is 'not much lower than the D.' This near-equality produces a fundamentally different behavioral approach: Inspirational people prefer to work with others through cooperation and persuasion rather than domination. They offer others what they want and need—such as power, security, or recognition—strategically to meet their own objectives. They are the quintessential 'movers and shakers' who initiate action and demand results.
core_strengths: Powerful influence over others' thoughts and actions
Initiates action as a 'mover and shaker'
weaknesses: Judges others by status and strength
Inspirational.communication_style: Persuasive and charming. Alternates between cooperation and domination. Offers people what they need to gain cooperation. More socially sophisticated than Developer or Results-Oriented. Uses emotional appeals strategically.
Inspirational.work_environment: Needs fun and variety. Frequent change desirable. Resists systematic, detailed work. Wants control of environment and objectives. Positions with visible social status and authority.
Inspirational.leadership_style: Leads through influence and persuasion rather than pure domination. Charismatic and inspirational. Sets predetermined goals and directs behavior toward them. Strategic—offers followers what they need in exchange for support. Most effective when making others feel success is shared.
Inspirational.stress_behaviors: Becomes manipulative, belligerent, or quarrelsome. 'Ends justify the means' thinking intensifies
motivation_drivers: Being seen as strong and influential
Inspirational.decision_making: Decisive with clear results in mind. More collaborative than Developer or Results-Oriented—considers how to bring others along. Still driven by own objectives but frames decisions to appeal to others.
Inspirational.conflict_style: Combination of charm and force. May alternate between persuasion and intimidation. Can become manipulative. Creates push-pull dynamics. Prefers winning through influence; resorts to aggression when charm fails.

Creative.disc_combination: D high (primary); C high (secondary); I and S low
Creative.description: The Creative pattern expresses opposing behavioral forces. These individuals desire immediate results (D) yet have an equally strong desire for perfection (C). You observe aggression tempered by sensitivity, quick thinking balanced by thorough option exploration. This internal tension between 'act fast' and 'be precise' produces both excellence and personal conflict. They want the freedom to explore and the authority to test and re-test findings. They are uniquely positioned as change agents because they combine the drive to push for results with the analytical rigor to ensure quality.
core_strengths: Innovative approaches combined with systematic development
weaknesses: Too demanding of self and others
Creative.communication_style: Private and restrained. Direct and blunt without softening messages. More comfortable with important messages in writing (C influence). Expects logic and supporting data from others. Should offer explanations of reasoning to gain cooperation.
Creative.work_environment: Freedom to explore and authority to test findings. Values both innovation and quality. Dislikes routine. Wants unique accomplishments. Needs independence but demands high standards. Prefers challenging goals with freedom to plan approach.
Creative.leadership_style: Resolute Leadership—determined, persistent, gives courage during hard times. Natural skeptics. Sets high standards. Spots inefficiencies. Has 'fighting spirit.' Creates rules and processes. May encourage too much research when action is needed. Might ignore emotional impact of logically sound decisions.
Creative.stress_behaviors: Becomes independent and bored. Sulks. Withdraws. Internal D/C conflict intensifies. Becomes more blunt and critical
motivation_drivers: Innovation and being a change agent
Creative.decision_making: Signature dual approach—daily/routine decisions are quick and easy (D leads), while major/significant decisions involve extreme caution (C leads). Weighs pros and cons. Explores all options before committing on important matters.
Creative.conflict_style: Faces issues head-on and seeks them out proactively. Uses logic and facts rather than emotions. May become blunt and demeaning toward perceived incompetence. Won't yield easily—fighting spirit. May sulk or withdraw rather than engage emotionally.

Promoter.disc_combination: I high (only dimension above midline); D, S, C all low
Promoter.description: Promoters are the quintessential people persons. Social and gregarious, they cast a large net of friends and colleagues and are exceptional at maintaining contact with their network. They are verbally skilled, generous with support for others' projects, and their extensive network provides resources for their own initiatives in return. They are more interested in interaction than accomplishment. Their personality radiates enthusiasm, spontaneity, openness, optimism, warmth, and expressiveness. They possess a magnetic quality—walking into a room of strangers feels like an opportunity, not a challenge.
weaknesses: Continues socializing when tasks need attention
Leaps to favorable conclusions without facts
Promoter.communication_style: Expressive, animated, casual, friendly. Prefers face-to-face over written communication. Uses stories, humor, and personal anecdotes. Appreciates when others match their energy. Wants flexible agendas with personal connection before business. Sensitive to criticism—needs positive feedback before areas for improvement.
Promoter.work_environment: Popularity and social recognition; freedom of expression; group activities; democratic relationships; freedom from control and detail; opportunities to verbalize proposals; favorable, friendly working conditions; variety and collaboration
Promoter.leadership_style: Leads through charm, charisma, and enthusiasm. Creates interactive, positive environments. Natural team-builder. Diffuses conflict using humor. Extremely persuasive. May take hands-off approach risking being seen as unresponsive. Places too much trust in others. Needs to be firmer with deadlines and accountability.
Promoter.decision_making: Intuitive and fast—gut feel over facts. Makes favorable assumptions without complete information. Tends to overestimate outcomes. Needs others who supply facts, data, and systematic approaches.
Promoter.conflict_style: Avoids conflict, hoping problems resolve. Uses humor to deflect. Prefers keeping things light. May smooth over without genuine resolution. Risk of personal attacks or talking over others when escalated.

Persuader.disc_combination: I high (primary); D moderate-high (secondary); S and C low
Persuader.description: Persuaders love working with and through people to accomplish their own objectives. Their outgoing and persuasive personalities easily gain support and respect. They impress others and sell themselves using 'winning ways.' What sets them apart from Promoters is the addition of Dominance energy—they don't just socialize, they socialize with purpose and drive. They are the most impulsive and persuasive of all I styles—fast-paced, active, charming, passionate, charismatic, bold, comfortable improvising, ambitious, self-promoting, and adventurous.
weaknesses: Gut-level approach needs more detail attention
Persuader.communication_style: Fast-paced, enthusiastic, animated, persuasive. Uses friendly, open manner. Judges others by flexibility and expressiveness. Engages with stories and high-level ideas. Discusses future possibilities rather than past details. More direct than Promoter due to D influence.
Persuader.work_environment: Working with people; challenging assignments; variety and mobility; opportunities for status and prestige; freedom from routine; fast-paced with new opportunities; brainstorming sessions
Persuader.leadership_style: Leads through enthusiasm and personal charm. Generates excitement for challenging goals. Bold and impulsive. Thrives in fast-paced or unconventional settings. Combines ownership of results with natural charisma. More results-driven than Promoter.
Persuader.stress_behaviors: Becomes indecisive and easily persuaded; organizes to 'look good' rather than genuinely; becomes scattered
Persuader.decision_making: Intuitive and fast, trusts gut instinct. Once alerted to importance of details, can use analytical data effectively. Benefits from systematic data, planning, and risk-management built into processes.
Persuader.conflict_style: Uses direct approach with proposed solutions. More willing to confront than Promoter due to D influence. Can become impatient during prolonged discussions. Combines persuasive charm with directness. May try to 'win' through force of personality.

Counselor.disc_combination: I high (primary); S moderate-high (secondary); D and C low
Counselor.description: Counselors embrace others with warmth, empathy, and understanding. They are long-term relationship builders, good listeners, and effective problem-solvers who use an indirect approach. They put people first, providing recognition and attributing less importance to task accomplishment. Of all DISC profiles, Counselors are probably the most effective at relating to other people in an all-round sense. They socialize easily and feel at ease with strangers. They are persuasive and charming, but the Steadiness element allows them to adopt a more open, relaxed approach—becoming less directly active and more receptive to others' ideas and feelings.
weaknesses: Indirect when issuing orders or disciplining
Counselor.communication_style: Shows kindness, empathy, and understanding. Lets others initiate action. Interested in meeting people. Usually calm and controlled. Uses indirect, gentle approach. Influences through sincere personal relationships and availability. Provides verbal encouragement. Avoids criticism and confrontation.
Counselor.work_environment: Collaborative, harmonious environments; friendship and peaceful surroundings; appreciation and recognition; stability and predictability; team-oriented with close working relationships; minimal conflict; opportunities to coach and develop others
Counselor.leadership_style: Friendly and collaborative. Creates warm, inclusive environments with strong team cohesion. May avoid necessary conflict. Provides adequate recognition. Leads by example of care and empathy. Prefers consensus-building over directive leadership. Difficulty making tough decisions or giving critical feedback.
Counselor.stress_behaviors: Becomes overly flexible and intimate; too trusting without differentiating; may use key friendships to influence outcomes
Counselor.decision_making: People-focused—considers human impact above all. Indirect and consensus-seeking. Difficulty making unpopular decisions. Prefers gathering input. Avoids decisions that might harm people. Benefits from external structure and deadlines.
Counselor.conflict_style: Strongly conflict-averse. Uses indirect approach. Approaches calmly and privately. Acknowledges feelings first. Focuses on solutions not blame. May tolerate negative situations rather than confronting. Will mediate between others. Takes criticism personally but responds well to gentle feedback.

Appraiser.disc_combination: I high (primary); C moderate-high (secondary); D and S low
Appraiser.description: The Appraiser is one of the rarest classical patterns because I and C are theoretically opposite dimensions—I is accepting/people-focused/fast-paced while C is questioning/logic-focused/moderate-paced. Appraisers tend to be strong communicators: C's measure words carefully while I's are naturally skilled at influencing others. The hallmark of this profile is that the individual may exhibit either influencing or compliance behaviors depending on the situation. The two factors constantly compete for behavioral 'governorship.' In social/trusting environments, the I side emerges; in structured/formal settings, the C side dominates. They have a strong drive to be successful and appear accomplished—reaching goals is important, but they want success with flair and triumph with style.
core_strengths: Strong communication blending measured words with natural influence
Verbal adeptness combined with analytical precision
weaknesses: Unpredictable behavior confuses colleagues (flips between I and C modes)
Under stress becomes critical, restless, impatient
Doesn't display empathy when expressing disapproval
Eagerness to win overrides social graces
Engages in bursts rather than steady pace
Appraiser.communication_style: Strong verbal communicators who measure words carefully. Assertive but considerate tone. Uses persuasion and involvement rather than commands. Explains rationale to elicit cooperation. In social situations: friendly, animated, engaging. In formal situations: more blunt, plain-speaking, driven. Discreetly wants attention.
Appraiser.work_environment: Environments balancing social interaction with quality standards; opportunities to lead team projects; settings allowing creative thinking AND structured execution; competitive with friendly rivalry; clear expectations with freedom to innovate
Appraiser.leadership_style: Leads through combination of persuasion and planning. Involves people through explanation. Helps teams visualize steps and goals. Values teamwork but craves authority. Uses courtesy but is assertive when necessary. Encourages friendly competition. May become authoritarian when standards aren't maintained.
Appraiser.stress_behaviors: Becomes restless, critical, impatient; may become authoritarian or caustic; verbal criticism increases; competitive drive intensifies
Appraiser.decision_making: Blends intuitive I-style thinking with analytical C-style evaluation. Makes creative ideas serve practical purposes. Develops detailed action plans. Prefers orderly, step-by-step progress. Can be decisive but may waver between gut instinct and analytical assessment.
Appraiser.conflict_style: Competitive—wants to 'win.' Uses persuasion first but can become authoritarian. May become caustic in criticism. Lacks empathy when expressing disapproval (growth area). When C-side dominates: may comply rather than confront. When I-side dominates: tries to communicate and influence.

Specialist.disc_combination: S high (only dimension above midline); D, I, C all low
Specialist.description: Specialists 'wear well' with others. With their moderate, controlled stance and modest demeanor, they work effectively with many behavioral styles. They are considerate, patient, and always ready to help those they consider friends. They build close relationships with a relatively small group of associates in the work environment, directing efforts toward retaining familiar and predictable patterns. Most effective in specialized areas, Specialists plan their work along directed channels and achieve a remarkably consistent performance. Appreciation from others helps maintain that level of consistency.
weaknesses: Overly cautious and resistant to change
Puts finished projects aside for further revision
May become demotivated if forced to change without reason
Specialist.communication_style: Prefers one-on-one over group settings. Answers when asked but prefers listening. Speaks calmly and amiably. Seeks trust during interactions. Explains things thoroughly. Indirect and non-confrontational. Signs of tension are subtle—may not speak up if offended.
Specialist.work_environment: Status quo maintained unless given clear reasons for change; predictable routines; credit and sincere appreciation for work; minimal work infringement on home life; identification with a group; minimal conflict; clearly defined expectations
Specialist.leadership_style: Authority based on experience and expertise. Comfortable maintaining routines. Prefers supportive/servant leadership. Leads by example through consistent performance. Works behind the scenes supporting others.
Specialist.stress_behaviors: Capitulates to authority; thinks with the group; passive resistance; withdraws; internalizes
Specialist.decision_making: Deliberate and methodical—needs time. Prefers proven approaches. Conservative. Requires clear information before deciding. Seeks consensus. Avoids decisions creating conflict.
Specialist.conflict_style: Avoids at almost all costs. Diffuses through calm, empathetic approaches. Values stability above resolution. May not speak up when offended. Lets things settle rather than engaging. May yield to end conflict, then hold resentment.

Agent.disc_combination: S high (primary); I moderate-high (secondary); D and C low
Agent.description: Agents are easygoing, relaxed, and go with the flow. Like the Counselor (I/S—their mirror image), they strive to maintain harmony and treat people with respect. A key distinction is that Agents tend to think of others first, then themselves. Their S (supportive) style is naturally empathetic, while the I (Influence) style adds enthusiasm. Agents exude a kind and generous spirit. They love team settings and appreciate environments ensuring stability and fostering long-term relationships with minimal change. Because they respond to others' needs, people do not fear being rejected by Agents.
core_strengths: Excellent task-related skills alongside people skills
Effective at organizing and completing tasks
weaknesses: Fear of conflict is primary weakness
Supportive approach may enable tolerance of bad situations rather than problem-solving
Agent.communication_style: Quiet, tactful, friendly, casual. Accept affection readily, reject aggression. Communicate with warmth and empathy. Use persuasion through information or key friendships. Prefer inclusive, respectful dialogue. Listen more than speak. Non-confrontational with indirect approaches.
Agent.work_environment: Team-based with stability and long-term relationships; minimal change and conflict; cooperative, supportive atmosphere; roles focused on service and helping; clear procedures; opportunities for meaningful connections
Agent.leadership_style: Leads through service and harmony-creation. Influences through empathy and friendship. Focuses on team cohesion and inclusion. Mediates conflicts. May struggle with tough, unpopular decisions. Supportive but may lack directness in accountability.
Agent.stress_behaviors: Becomes persuasive using information or friendships; retreats to low profile; enables rather than confronts
motivation_drivers: Being valued for service and empathy
Agent.decision_making: Considers impact on relationships and group harmony first. Prefers consensus. Takes time for all perspectives. May defer to others to avoid conflict. Uses emotional intelligence. Can be influenced by key friendships.
Agent.conflict_style: Strongly avoids direct confrontation but willing to mediate between others. Uses empathy and gentle persuasion. May enable problems by not addressing directly. Adopts 'low profile' with aggressive individuals. Under pressure, uses key friendships as leverage.

Achiever.disc_combination: S high (primary); D moderate-high (secondary); I and C low
Achiever.description: Achievers have a strong sense of personal accountability and are confident of their work accomplishments. They may be reluctant to delegate when stressed. They thrive with a strong sense of direction and are continually pursuing new accomplishments. The dual S/D style makes it difficult to predict their reactions—sometimes in D mode (direct, results-oriented), other times in S mode (caring, accommodating). They express fierce loyalty to people in their lives. While their D nature focuses on results, their S nature cares about fairness and respect. This makes them natural champions of equality and justice.
core_strengths: Combines patience (S) with drive (D) for unwavering determination
Switches between caring and direct as needed
weaknesses: Difficulty compromising short-term for long-range benefits
Unpredictable reactions due to S/D tension
Achiever.communication_style: In D mode: direct, assertive, results-focused. In S mode: patient, empathetic, accommodating. Style can shift unpredictably. Values clear, results-oriented discussion balanced with fairness. More willing to speak up than other S-types, especially for causes they believe in.
Achiever.work_environment: Strong direction and control over work; opportunities for personal accomplishment; recognition equal to contribution; clear task priorities; ability to work independently; part of high-performing teams with competent colleagues; environments valuing both results and fairness
Achiever.leadership_style: Leads by personal example and accountability. Champions equality and justice. Can be directive (D) or supportive (S) depending on situation. Expects high standards. Reluctant to delegate. Strong personal responsibility for outcomes. May struggle fully empowering others.
Achiever.stress_behaviors: Frustrated and impatient; becomes more of a 'doer' and less of a 'delegator'; takes on more work personally; shows D-mode behavior more prominently
motivation_drivers: Internal goals and deeply felt ambitions
Achiever.decision_making: Internally motivated based on personal goals. Blends methodical S with decisive D. Quick to take personal accountability. May default to 'I'll do it myself.' 'Either/or' thinking can limit alternatives.
Achiever.conflict_style: More willing to engage than other S-types due to D influence. Speaks up assertively for fairness and justice. Champions the underdog. May oscillate between D-mode (confrontational) and S-mode (accommodating). Unpredictable responses due to dual-nature tension.

Investigator.disc_combination: S high (primary); D and C both above midline (secondary); I is the only dimension below midline
Investigator.description: Investigators are objective, analytical, and dispassionate 'anchors of reality.' Generally undemonstrative, they calmly and steadily pursue an independent path toward a fixed goal. They are successful at many things not because of versatility but due to dogged determination to follow through. Once a project begins, Investigators fight tenaciously to achieve objectives. Intervention is sometimes necessary to change their direction—they can be perceived as stubborn and opinionated. They thrive on challenging technical assignments where they can use logic instead of emotion. They are not especially interested in pleasing people and prefer to work alone.
core_strengths: Comprehensive task completion with detail attention
Combines patience (S) with drive (D) and precision (C)
weaknesses: Reluctant to let others carry the load
Needs greater understanding of others' emotions
Investigator.communication_style: Persistent, analytical, cautious, disciplined. Responds to logic rather than emotion. Prefers factual, data-driven discussions. Direct and sometimes blunt. Influences through personal tenacity rather than charm. May be terse or distant. Values factual, reliable information.
Investigator.work_environment: Challenging technical assignments; opportunities for data and logical analysis; ability to work alone or in small groups; clear goals for developing plans; formal roles with position authority; environments valuing quality and thoroughness; freedom from extensive social demands
Investigator.leadership_style: Leads through determination and personal example. Authority from formal roles and titles. Task-focused—drives toward fixed goals. Not a 'people person' leader. Effective with technical teams. Expects factual, logical thinking. Can be perceived as stubborn and controlling.
Investigator.stress_behaviors: Internalizes conflict; holds grudges; becomes more distant and blunt; more suspicious of others; retreats into solo work
motivation_drivers: Power through formal roles and position authority
Investigator.decision_making: Highly analytical—uses data and facts to interpret information. Develops orderly plans. Once direction is set, pursues with single-minded determination. May be slow to change course even when evidence suggests adjustment. Evaluates others by use of factual information. Responds to logic over emotion.
Investigator.conflict_style: Internalizes rather than expressing openly. Holds grudges. Uses logic and facts when engaging. May become blunt and direct (D influence) when pushed. Doesn't seek people-pleasing resolution—wants the 'correct' outcome. Prefers avoiding emotional confrontation. Distrustful of others' motives. If conflict persists, withdraws to work independently.

Objective_Thinker.disc_combination: C high (only dimension above midline); D, I, S all low
Objective_Thinker.description: Objective Thinkers have highly developed critical thinking abilities. They emphasize the importance of facts when drawing conclusions and planning actions, seeking correctness and accuracy in everything. They continually question ideas and processes to ensure things are done properly. They are systematic, practical, and efficient. To manage work effectively, they often combine intuitive information with gathered facts. When in doubt, they avoid public failure by preparing meticulously—mastering new skills privately before using them in group settings. Despite being mild-mannered, they have a strong need to control their environment, exerting this control indirectly by requiring adherence to rules and standards.
core_strengths: Highly developed critical and analytical thinking
Exceptional at gathering, evaluating, and testing information
Combines intuitive insight with factual data
Objective_Thinker.communication_style: Indirect and guarded—cautious and reflective. Prefers fact-based, logical exchanges. Reticent about personal feelings. Measures words carefully. Prefers written or well-prepared presentations. Avoids emotional language. Dislikes pressure for immediate responses.
Objective_Thinker.work_environment: Reserved, business-like atmosphere; clearly defined expectations; quality and accuracy valued; opportunities to demonstrate expertise; control over performance factors; opportunity to ask 'why' questions; peaceful, aggression-free; independent work with minimal interruptions
Objective_Thinker.leadership_style: Leads through expertise and standards. Exerts control indirectly through rules and procedures. Values quality and competency above all. Ensures accuracy and avoids costly mistakes. May slow decision-making. Leads by example and mastery rather than charisma. May struggle providing emotional support.
Objective_Thinker.stress_behaviors: Worrisome and anxious; immerses in more analysis; withdraws socially; becomes rigid about rules; avoids acknowledging mistakes
Objective_Thinker.decision_making: Highly analytical and data-driven. Bases decisions on logical analysis of quantifiable information. Avoids emotional influence. Concerned with finding the 'right' answer. Struggles with ambiguity. Gets bogged down when uncertain. Prepares meticulously.
Objective_Thinker.conflict_style: Strongly avoids interpersonal aggression. Uses subtle, indirect approaches. Controls through rules rather than confrontation. Withdraws rather than engaging directly. Uses facts and data to resolve disagreements. Uncomfortable with aggressive people. May search for supporting data rather than admitting error.

Perfectionist.disc_combination: C high (primary); S moderate-high (secondary); D and I low
Perfectionist.description: 'If it can't be done right, then why do it at all'—the Perfectionist's mantra. C/S styles are driven by a need for accuracy and logic. The C provides precision while the S adds patience, resulting in an individual with intense quality focus. They are systematic, precise thinkers who follow procedures in both personal and professional life. Extremely conscientious, they are diligent with work requiring detail and accuracy. Because they desire stable conditions and predictable activities, they are most comfortable in clearly defined work environments with specifics on expectations, time requirements, and evaluation procedures.
core_strengths: Exceptional quality control and standard maintenance
weaknesses: Perfectionist nature causes stress and anxiety
May be late delivering due to unrealistic standards
Controlling—finds something wrong in others' work
Needs more role flexibility and self-worth belief
Perfectionist.communication_style: Reserved, deliberate, measured. Displays competence and restraint. Non-demonstrative. Prefers logical, fact-based discussions. More warm than pure C due to S influence but still guarded. May internalize concerns. Prefers written or structured formats. Their silence doesn't mean everything is fine.
Perfectionist.work_environment: Clearly defined expectations with specific time requirements and evaluation procedures; stable, predictable conditions; quality-focused atmosphere; established procedures; structured roles; behind-the-scenes rather than spotlight; minimal conflict and antagonism; stability with minimal chaos
Perfectionist.leadership_style: Servant leader mindset—fair-minded and appreciative of different strengths. Humble. Prioritizes reliability and quality. Aims to lessen uncertainty for team. Enjoys supporting people to do their best work. Patient and methodical. Creates stable, quality-focused environments. May struggle with rapid change and conflict management.
Perfectionist.stress_behaviors: Becomes tactful and diplomatic (withdraws into safety); resorts to familiar procedures; becomes inflexible; appeals to conventional methods; resists change; may freeze or become passive; passive-aggressive tactics possible
motivation_drivers: Adequate time to plan and verify
Perfectionist.decision_making: Methodical and thorough. Gathers extensive information. Questions assumptions and analyzes alternatives. May be criticized for time taken. Requires extensive data. Likes managers' opinions but takes risks when armed with facts. Prefers proven methods. Risk-averse unless supported by strong evidence.
Perfectionist.conflict_style: Naturally conflict-averse—values stability. Prefers staying objective and returning to stable footing. Uses tact and diplomacy under pressure. Fears antagonism deeply. May become passive or use passive-aggressive tactics. Tends to let issues simmer. Productive: focuses on facts, listens, gives space. Growth area: engaging directly.

Practitioner.disc_combination: C high (primary); I and S both above midline (secondary); D is the only dimension below midline
Practitioner.description: Practitioners value proficiency in specialized areas. Spurred by a desire to be 'good at something,' they carefully monitor their own work performance. Although their aim is to be 'the' expert in an area, they frequently give the impression of knowing something about everything—an image strengthened when they verbalize knowledge on many subjects. As they interact, they project a relaxed, diplomatic, and easygoing style (I and S influence). This congenial attitude may change quickly in their own work area when they become intensely focused on meeting high performance standards. They are uniquely skilled in both technical and people problem-solving—the only C-family pattern combining analytical precision with social awareness and patience.
core_strengths: Skilled in both technical and people problem-solving
Combines analytical precision with social awareness
weaknesses: Overattention to personal objectives at expense of team goals
Reluctance to lead or take accountability for major decisions
Reluctance to move fast frustrates colleagues
Overly sensitive to criticism under pressure
May give impression of knowing everything (can seem pretentious)
Practitioner.communication_style: Relaxed, diplomatic, easygoing in social interactions (most sociable of C-family). Pleasant, courteous, restrained. Verbalizes knowledge confidently on many subjects. Shifts from congenial to intensely focused within work domain. Diplomatic and tactful with indirect approaches. More warm and accepting than Objective Thinker or Perfectionist. Will verbalize disappointment when standards aren't met.
Practitioner.work_environment: Comfortable and cooperative atmosphere; trusting, pleasant people; detail-oriented projects; opportunities for specialized expertise; recognition as expert; supportive (not leadership) roles; structured with clear procedures; team-oriented; environments valuing self-discipline and quality; stability mixed with enough variety to avoid predictability
Practitioner.leadership_style: Prefers NOT to lead—favors supportive, collaborative roles. When leading, acts as subject-matter expert and mentor. Influences through skill demonstration and proper procedures. Sets high expectations and monitors performance. More people-aware than other C-family leaders. Needs to delegate rather than handling everything personally. Should take more risks.
stress_triggers: Being seen as too predictable or ordinary
Practitioner.stress_behaviors: Becomes restrained and withdrawn; overly sensitive to criticism; voices disapproval more sharply; puts personal objectives first; retreats to area of expertise; becomes rigid about procedures
motivation_drivers: Supporting and interacting with others on meaningful projects
Practitioner.decision_making: Prefers not to make major decisions or take risks. Needs ample time to think. Brings valuable insights when given time. Bases decisions on expertise and procedures. More cautious than fast. Comfortable within area of expertise. Combines analytical thinking with people-impact consideration (I and S).
Practitioner.conflict_style: Diplomatic and accommodating—prefers harmony (S and I influence). Values cooperative environments. Verbalizes disapproval when expectations unmet (may seem passive-aggressive). Becomes restrained and sensitive under pressure. Resolves through proper procedures. More comfortable addressing indirectly. Uses social skills (I) to smooth over. Patient enough (S) to wait for resolution. May withdraw rather than escalate.

pattern_determination.algorithm: Count dimensions above midline threshold. For 1 dimension: assign pure style. For 2 dimensions: identify primary/secondary and map to pattern. For D/I combination: calculate gap—small gap = Inspirational, large gap = Results-Oriented. For 3 dimensions: S+D+C = Investigator, C+I+S = Practitioner.
pattern_determination.scoring_notes: Each dimension ranges 0-24. Scores above 16 (65% of maximum) indicate high expression. Primary = highest score, Secondary = second-highest.

differentiation_guide.Developer_vs_Results_Oriented: Results-Oriented uses I secondary as social leverage for results. Developer is more purely self-reliant.
differentiation_guide.Results_Oriented_vs_Inspirational: Gap between D and I scores. D clearly dominates = Results-Oriented. D and I nearly equal = Inspirational.
differentiation_guide.Promoter_vs_Persuader: Persuader adds D-driven purpose. Promoters socialize for connection; Persuaders socialize with ambition.
differentiation_guide.Counselor_vs_Agent: Mirror patterns. Counselor (I/S) more socially proactive. Agent (S/I) more grounded, thinks of others first.
differentiation_guide.Achiever_vs_Investigator: Investigator adds C (analytical). Achiever driven by personal accountability; Investigator by technical mastery.
differentiation_guide.Objective_Thinker_vs_Perfectionist: Perfectionist adds S (patience, stability). Objective Thinker explores novel approaches; Perfectionist clings to procedures.
differentiation_guide.Perfectionist_vs_Practitioner: Practitioner adds I (social awareness). Perfectionist works behind scenes; Practitioner most socially comfortable C pattern.
